awd_titl_txt: GOALI: An Electrochemical Atomic Layer Deposition Process for Scalable Nanomanufacturing of On-chip Copper-based Interconnects
awd_abstract_narration:
Advanced nanoelectronic circuits in microprocessors and memory devices utilize current-carrying copper interconnects. In modern devices, interconnect widths routinely approach a few tens of nanometers. However, the need for high interconnect packing density in high-performance computing drives a commensurate shrinking in the interconnect width in accordance with Moore's law. By the year 2020, interconnect widths are expected to shrink well below ten nanometers. A critical hurdle in driving such aggressive interconnect size reduction is the unavailability of an interconnect fabrication process with the following attributes: (i) Unprecedented atomic-level control needed to manipulate materials at the nanometer scale or below; and (ii) Ease of scale-up and integration with large-area substrates yielding reliable, low-cost manufacturability. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) Program award will explore a novel approach towards nano-scale interconnect fabrication with the aforementioned attributes. This is critical for safeguarding Moore's law and for ensuring that the US semiconductor industry continues to maintain technological leadership in advanced nanoelectronics. This research will have broad impacts not just in the field of nanoelectronics, but also in many other areas central to the US economy and society, such as advanced energy systems and environmental remediation. In addition to enabling breakthroughs in scalable nanomanufacturing, this research will provide experiential engineering education and professional development to the next generation of scientists and engineers highly sought after by the US industry.

The goal of the project is to study a novel electrochemical atomic layer deposition (e-ALD) process for the scalable nanomanufacturing of copper and copper-alloy interconnects. In spite of its enormous potential, state-of-the-art electrochemical atomic layer deposition of copper has not reached commercial viability primarily due to its low throughput, use of toxic metals, such as lead, and its inability to fabricate specific copper-alloys of relevance to nanoelectronic applications. To overcome these barriers, a 'one-step' lead-free electrochemical atomic layer deposition process will be investigated. Through fundamental characterization of the interplay between the electrode potential and the electrolyte chemistry, and through use of novel, environmentally benign electrolyte components, one-step deposition of copper and copper-alloy nano-films will be achieved. The project will eliminate a key technological roadblock in industrial-scale implementation of electrochemical atomic layer deposition technology for the metallization of nano-scale copper interconnects. An inter-disciplinary team of academic and industrial scientists will collaborate on the research through the exchange of knowledge in cutting-edge electrochemistry and advanced nanoelectronics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
This project was a university-industry collaborative effort led by Case Western Reserve University in collaboration with Lam Research Corporation. The project aimed at developing the fundamental foundations of a novel materials fabrication process called electrochemical atomic layer deposition. The key hallmark of this process is that it enables materials fabrication with atomic precision such that nano-materials can be fabricated essentially one atomic layer at a time. Such precise nano-manufacturing of materials is of critical need in various field such as nano-electronics and electrocatalysis. Potential near-term application of atomically-precise fabrication is in metallization of miniaturized interconnects in semiconductor devices thereby safeguarding Moore's law which guides the continual improvements of integrated circuits used in virtually every aspect of modern life. In this project, electrochemical atomic layer deposition of a variety of materials including copper and cobalt was demonstrated. By employing surface-limited reactions, metal deposition was limited to one atomic layer in each deposition cycle. Multilayered metal films could be fabricated by repeating these cycles. Electrochemical and atomically-resolved microcopic methods of characterization confirmed atomic-scale layer-by-layer assembly of films. The industry collaboration enabled scale-up of the process to practically-relevant substrates including silicon wafers. Process benefits such as environmental benignity, high throughput, low cost, and versatility were demonstrated, leading to active industry interest in integrating the electrochemical atomic layer deposition process in silicon wafer processing of future nano-electronics devices. Fundamental processes of diffusion and electrochemical reactions were investigated leading to a mathematical process model which can be used to design and tailor processes of such kind for customized applications. A graduate student, three undergraduate students and two high-school students performed research in electrochemistry and materials processing leading to numerous peer-reviewed publications in reputed international journals, and several invited presentations at conferences, industries and at universities around the world. Students were exposed to unique industry interactions including internships contributing to professional development and improved communication and project management skills. Graduate student is now employed in the US semiconductor industry with the industry collaborator (Lam Research Corporation), and several undergraduate students are now enrolled in top-ranking graduate (Ph.D.) programs in chemical engineering at US universities.


Last Modified: 06/29/2019
Modified by: Rohan N Akolkar
